articles.headline: Rupert Murdoch’s Retirement Raises the Curtain on His Next Act
articles.snippet: The media mogul has stepped back from the forefront of his empire, but there’s likely more to come — like a step to cement power for his son Lachlan.
articles.abstract: The media mogul has stepped back from the forefront of his empire, but there’s likely more to come — like a step to cement power for his son Lachlan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch’s announcement on Thursday that he was stepping back from day-to-day oversight of his media empire cleared the way for his elder son, Lachlan, to claim sole oversight of the businesses.

articles.headline: How a Storied National Airline Became Reviled in Its Own Country
articles.snippet: A string of scandals has left Qantas Airways, which calls itself “the spirit of Australia,” near the bottom of public opinion at home.
articles.abstract: A string of scandals has left Qantas Airways, which calls itself “the spirit of Australia,” near the bottom of public opinion at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barely three years after its entire fleet was grounded, Qantas Airways has never been more profitable. But as Australia’s national airline has emerged stronger from the pandemic, it has alienated its most important constituency: Australians.

articles.headline: Blasting Bullhorns and Water Cannons, Chinese Ships Wall Off the Sea
articles.snippet: The world’s most brazen maritime militarization is gaining muscle in waters through which one-third of global ocean trade passes.
articles.abstract: The world’s most brazen maritime militarization is gaining muscle in waters through which one-third of global ocean trade passes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Chinese military base on Mischief Reef, off the Philippine island of Palawan, loomed in front of our boat, obvious even in the predawn dark.
articles.byline: By Hannah Beech and Jes Aznar

articles.headline: Netflix Prepares to Send Its Final Red Envelope
articles.snippet: The company’s DVD subscription service is ending this month, bringing to a close an origin story that ultimately upended the entertainment industry.
articles.abstract: The company’s DVD subscription service is ending this month, bringing to a close an origin story that ultimately upended the entertainment industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a nondescript office park minutes from Disneyland sits a nondescript warehouse. Inside this nameless, faceless building, an era is ending.
articles.byline: By Nicole Sperling and Mark Abramson

articles.headline: U.S. Army Hospital in Germany Is Treating Americans Hurt Fighting in Ukraine
articles.snippet: The Army’s Landstuhl Regional Medical Center has quietly started admitting Ukrainian Army soldiers who were wounded in combat, most of them American volunteers.
articles.abstract: The Army’s Landstuhl Regional Medical Center has quietly started admitting Ukrainian Army soldiers who were wounded in combat, most of them American volunteers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A group of Ukrainian Army soldiers pierced by Russian grenades and mortar shells arrived at a hospital recently in need of surgery. It would have been a familiar scene from the bloody war grinding on in Ukraine, except for two crucial differences: Most of the wounded soldiers were American, and so was the hospital — the U.S. Army’s flagship medical center in Germany.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: The Wrecking-Ball Caucus: How the Far Right Brought Washington to Its Knees
articles.snippet: Right-wing Republicans who represent a minority in their party and in Congress have succeeded in sowing mass dysfunction, spoiling for a shutdown, an impeachment and a House coup.
articles.abstract: Right-wing Republicans who represent a minority in their party and in Congress have succeeded in sowing mass dysfunction, spoiling for a shutdown, an impeachment and a House coup.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to his view of the United States government, Representative Bob Good, a right-wing Republican who represents a Virginia district that was once the domain of Thomas Jefferson, doesn’t mince words.

articles.headline: TV Networks’ Last Best Hope: Boomers
articles.snippet: Viewers have fled prime-time lineups for streaming outlets, with one notable exception: people over 60.
articles.abstract: Viewers have fled prime-time lineups for streaming outlets, with one notable exception: people over 60.
articles.lead_paragraph: This coming week, as the network fall television season gets underway, ABC will begin airing “The Golden Bachelor,” a spinoff of “The Bachelor” that centers on an offbeat twist: The main contestant is a 72-year-old man, and the 22 women vying for his affection range in age from 60 to 75.

articles.headline: Where Did All the Dark-Suited Japanese Businessmen Go?
articles.snippet: Under “Cool Biz,” salarymen and government workers don short-sleeved shirts in the summer as offices are kept above 82 degrees Fahrenheit to save energy.
articles.abstract: Under “Cool Biz,” salarymen and government workers don short-sleeved shirts in the summer as offices are kept above 82 degrees Fahrenheit to save energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the tail end of another long, hot Tokyo summer, and salarymen across the city were looking at their wardrobes with dread.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno

articles.headline: Clams Ruled This Town Until the Crabs Moved In
articles.snippet: Goro, on the Adriatic Sea, is famous for its clams — essential for the beloved spaghetti alle vongole. But an infestation of crabs is threatening the town’s cash crop.
articles.abstract: Goro, on the Adriatic Sea, is famous for its clams — essential for the beloved spaghetti alle vongole. But an infestation of crabs is threatening the town’s cash crop.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before dawn in Goro, on the Adriatic Sea, Massimo Genari drove by the central roundabout, with its sculpture of two concrete clams in a net, and under a billboard of a mollusk donning a crimson royal crown. Wearing waders, he boarded his boat and motored to the lagoon with scores of other fishermen to rake the clam gardens that for decades have transformed this sleepy Italian village off the Po River Delta into a bivalve boomtown.

articles.headline: Dana Perino of Fox News Is About to Face Her Biggest Test as a Journalist
articles.snippet: The former press secretary in the Bush White House will moderate the next Republican debate. She’s managed to rise at Fox without being a Trump supplicant.
articles.abstract: The former press secretary in the Bush White House will moderate the next Republican debate. She’s managed to rise at Fox without being a Trump supplicant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dana Perino can punch and parry with the best of them. But she could be better at ducking.

articles.headline: As Trump Prosecutions Move Forward, Threats and Concerns Increase
articles.snippet: As criminal cases proceed against the former president, heated rhetoric and anger among his supporters have the authorities worried about the risk of political dissent becoming deadly.
articles.abstract: As criminal cases proceed against the former president, heated rhetoric and anger among his supporters have the authorities worried about the risk of political dissent becoming deadly.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the federal courthouse in Washington, a woman called the chambers of the judge assigned to the election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump and said that if Mr. Trump were not re-elected next year, “we are coming to kill you.”
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Adam Goldman, Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: Greece, Battered a Decade Ago, Is Booming
articles.snippet: It is one of Europe’s fastest-growing economies, and while investors and tourists are flocking to the country, memories of austerity measures are still fresh for Greeks.
articles.abstract: It is one of Europe’s fastest-growing economies, and while investors and tourists are flocking to the country, memories of austerity measures are still fresh for Greeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Paris Skouros pointed toward the sky outside his office in Athens on a recent weekday. In the past six months, four high-rises had sprung up, built by Greek and international builders to be sold for use as tourist rentals, foreign real estate investments and company offices. Farther afield, a fresh crop of new buildings dotted the horizon.

articles.headline: Finland Raced to Join NATO. What Happens Next Is Complicated.
articles.snippet: After decades of going it alone in security issues, Finns are finding that life in a large alliance is complex, expensive and deeply political.
articles.abstract: After decades of going it alone in security issues, Finns are finding that life in a large alliance is complex, expensive and deeply political.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barely a year after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Finland cast aside decades of military nonalignment and self-reliance and joined the NATO alliance.

articles.headline: ChatGPT Can Now Respond With Spoken Words
articles.snippet: A new version of OpenAI’s popular chatbot behaves a lot like Siri and Alexa. You can talk to it — and have a conversation.
articles.abstract: A new version of OpenAI’s popular chatbot behaves a lot like Siri and Alexa. You can talk to it — and have a conversation.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz, Brian X. Chen and Karen Weise

articles.headline: The Secret Ingredient of ChatGPT Is Human Advice
articles.snippet: Companies like OpenAI hone their bots using hand-tailored examples from well-educated workers. But is this always for the best?
articles.abstract: Companies like OpenAI hone their bots using hand-tailored examples from well-educated workers. But is this always for the best?
articles.lead_paragraph: Last November, the company behind Facebook released a chatbot called Galactica. After a torrent of complaints that the bot made up historical events and spewed other nonsense, Meta removed it from the internet.
